trade.title: Trade
keyTrends: Total plastic imports fell sharply from 977 million USD in 2017 to 419 million USD in 2020, partially reverting to 746 million USD in 2022.
Plastic exports rose to 411 million in 2022, driven by a sharp increase in primary polymer exports (278 million USD), which exceeded primary imports that year.
Imports are dominated by primary polymers, tyres, and finished goods, indicating reliance on foreign resins, rubber manufacturing, and consumer products.

While intermediate plastics show two-way trade and final goods exports remain stable (~90 million USD annually), imports significantly exceed exports, signalling constrained domestic production capacity.
{{country}} is heavily dependent on Asia for plastic supply, with exports oriented mainly toward Asia and Africa, reflecting integration into external supply chains.
Plastic waste imports are small, while exports increased in 2022, suggesting that recoverable materials are being shipped out due to limited domestic recycling capacity.
trade.summaryLeft:
Plastic Imports

A total of 4,504 million USD worth of plastic was imported to {{country}} between 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, the total imports reached value of 746 million USD, of which:

  • ~ 35% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 13% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 10% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 42% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

Plastic exports

A total of 1,406 million USD worth of plastic was exported from {{country}} in the year(s) 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, exports reached a value of USD 441 million, of which:

  • ~ 63% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 11% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 2% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 21% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 3% was plastic waste.
trade.summary:
Plastic trade trends

Lebanon’s plastic trade was highly volatile between 2017 and 2022, reflecting broader economic instability and the sharp contraction in 2020. Total plastic imports fell from 977 million in 2017 to 419 million in 2020, before partially recovering to 746 million in 2022.

Exports were relatively stable between 2017 and 2022 (156-299 million USD) but surged in 2022 to 441 million USD. This was driven by a sharp increase in primary plastic exports, which rose to 278 million USD in 2022, which is 65% of total plastic exports. Primary plastic imports declined significantly between 2017 and 2020, before recovering to 264 million USD in 2022, indicating reduced industrial demand during the COVID-19 pandemic and a partial recovery thereafter.

Intermediate plastics show consistent two-way trade. Imports remain higher than exports, but exports have grown moderately, suggesting a functioning converting sector. However, the scale of exports indicates that midstream processing is limited relative to domestic demand.

Final manufactured goods are the largest import category throughout the period. Imports declined sharply in 2020 and recovered to 311 million USD in 2022, highlighting contraction and rebound in consumer and packaging demand. Exports of final goods remain relatively stable (around 90 million USD annually), indicating a modest downstream manufacturing base, but imports substantially exceed exports.

The plastic waste trade is small relative to the total plastics trade. Imports remain under 1 million USD, while exports increased to over 12 million USD in 2022, suggesting outward shipment of recoverable materials rather than strong domestic recycling capacity.
trade.tradingPartners:
{{country}}’s plastics trade is strongly concentrated in Asia and Europe on the import side, and Asia and Africa on the export side.

Asia is by far the dominant supplier, accounting for approximately 544 million USD of total plastic imports. This reflects heavy reliance on Asian producers for primary resins, intermediate materials, and finished goods.

Europe is the second largest supplier (135 million USD), indicating continued trade integration with European industrial markets. Imports from Africa and the Americas are comparatively small, while Oceania plays a negligible role.
trade.productCategories: The World Trade Organisation’s database provides additional insight into the structure of {{country}}’s plastics economy. Here, we focus on plastics, synthetic textiles, and rubber trade categories, where HS-level data highlights a plastics economy that is structurally import-dependent but export-concentrated in specific polymer categories. Imports are dominated by plastics and articles thereof (HS Chapter 39), followed by textiles, apparel and footwear (HS chapters 54-65), then rubber (HS Chapter 40). Key imports include ethylene polymers (98 million USD), synthetic resins and polyesters (68 million USD), and plastic sheets and films (61 million USD), confirming strong reliance on imported virgin resins and semi-processed plastic materials. Rubber imports are heavily concentrated in new pneumatic tyres (102 million USD), indicating limited or no domestic tyre production. Textile, apparel and footwear imports reflect significant consumer demand and reliance on foreign manufacturing. Exports show a markedly different structure. While exports of plastics and articles thereof are substantial (384 million USD), they are highly concentrated in primary polymer materials, particularly synthetic resins and polyesters (267 million USD). Additional exports include plastic sheets and films (34 million USD) and plastic packaging products (25 million USD), indicating some converting capacity. In contrast, textile, apparel, and footwear exports (42 million USD) and rubber exports (4 million USD) remain comparatively small.

consumption.title: Consumption
consumption.content:
Plastic consumption is calculated as total imports minus exports, using UNCTAD data, and shows significant volatility between 2017 and 2022. Consumption declined from 772 million USD in 2017 to 601 million USD in 2019, before collapsing to 263 million USD in 2020.

Although consumption partially recovered in 2021 (407 million USD), it fell again in 2022 to 305 million USD. The surge in primary plastic exports in 2022 significantly reduced net domestic consumption, indicating that more material left the economy than was absorbed internally. Overall, the data suggests that {{country}}’s plastic consumption has structurally declined since 2017 and remains well below pre-pandemic levels.

wasteManagement.title: Waste Management
keyTrends: Municipal solid waste (MSW) generation remains substantial, with high collection coverage reported nationally, yet significant plastic emissions (including debris and open burning) persist.
Plastic leakage occurs primarily at collection stages, indicating that losses occur early in the waste management chain.
In several municipalities (e.g., Byblos 95%, Tyre 86%, Beirut and Ghobeiry 63%), most of the leakage is attributed to the MSW generation stage, rather than downstream handling.
Uncollected plastic waste is predominantly recorded as ending up on land and in water systems, with notable per-capita leakage in coastal municipalities.
Data gaps remain significant, particularly for recycling rates and non-municipal plastic waste streams, limiting full system transparency.
wasteManagement.content:
Plastic waste from municipal solid waste

An estimated 1,474 thousand tonnes of municipal solid waste were generated in {{country}} in 2020. A study on global waste management modeling showed 96% of municipal solid waste is collection coverage, with annual plastic emission including both debris and open burning is 43,520 tonnes per year, which is equivalent to 8 kg/person/year. Marine Litter Baseline study conducted in 2021 showed that waste collection coverage in Byblos and Tyre is 82% and 78%, respectively, lower than the modeling result. This was identified as one of the main sources of plastic pollution in {{country}}, contributing 95% in Byblos, 86% in Tyre and 63% in Beirut and Ghobeiry of plastic leakage into the environment from municipal solid waste management system. The same study identified that 73 potential new dumpsites may have opened on the banks of Lebanese rivers since 2017, which act as pathways for marine litter. On average, 3.1 kg/person/year of plastic waste escaped from SWM systems of the seven cities studied, and ended up in the environment.

The estimated MSW generation per capita in {{country}} in 2020 was 0.71 kg per person per day.

Data from selected city case studies provide further insights into waste management in {{country}}. Primary data collection through a waste composition survey undertaken recorded that the share of plastic waste within the collected waste was 10% in Byblos in 2021, and 14% in Tyre in 2021. The same primary data collection estimated that the per capita MSW generation in Byblos was 0.85 kg and in Tyre was 0.64 kg per person per day.

Reported environmental leakage from municipal solid waste management systems varies significantly across cities, depending on their waste collection coverage:

  • Tyre: 6.6 kg/person/year
  • Byblos: 5.9 kg/person/year
  • Beirut: 3.3 kg/person/year
  • Beddaoui: 3.1 kg/person/year
  • Ghobeiry: 2.7 kg/person/year
  • Ghazir: 2.2 kg/person/year
  • Aadoussiyeh: 1.1 kg/person/year

Leakage into water systems from municipal solid waste management systems is substantial in several locations:

  • Byblos: 2.9 kg/person/year
  • Tyre: 1.1 kg/person/year
  • Beddaoui and Ghazir: 0.9 kg/person/year
  • Beirut: 0.8 kg/person/year
  • Ghobeiry: 0.6 kg/person/year
  • Aadoussiyeh: 0.4 kg/person/year
wasteManagement.contentRight:
Plastic waste from non-municipal solid waste

Data on plastic waste generated outside the MSW stream is limited in available national statistics. The absence of consolidated reporting suggests potential under-monitoring of non-municipal plastic flows.

environment.title: Plastics in the Environment
keyTrends: Hard plastics, soft plastics and foam make up 77.7% of all marine litter found on the Lebanese beaches.
Hotspots emerge clearly. Beddaoui (Tripoli) and Jadra (Chouf) were the main hotspots of marine plastic litter found in both April and October 2021.
Uncollected waste, direct littering by beach goers and uncontrolled disposal sites are the main sources of marine litter.
Substantial fractions of uncollected plastic waste ending up in land and water systems, with per-capita leakage highest in Tyre and Byblos.
Most items on the seafloor, in surface waters, and in sediments were found in Byblos relative to other surveyed sites, and riverine/coastal interfaces show persistent microplastic loads.
environment.content:
Beach litter

The national average count of plastic beach litter items in {{country}} has increased from 1,337,026 to 2,374,286 items per km² between 2018 and 2019.

Common plastic items in the environment

Field monitoring data from Marine Litter Baseline study conducted in 2021 shows the most frequently recorded marine litter items are consistently plastic fragments and packaging-related items across multiple coastal sites:

  • Hard plastic fragments: ~4,003–5,829 items
  • Polystyrene fragments: ~3,967–4,499 items
  • Soft plastic fragments: ~2,409–3,020 items
  • Bottle caps/lids: ~1,525–2,061 items
  • Cigarette butts: ~691–2,755 items
  • Plastic beverage bottles: ~621–1,569 items
  • Soft plastic cups/lids: ~904–2,055 items
  • Multilayer food packaging: ~392–1,195 items
  • Straws: ~566–614 items

Material ranking data from CSIRO surveys (Fall 2021) confirms that plastics dominate the litter stream by both count and weight. Hard plastics account for ~22% of total material weight (56,207 g; 11,841 items), making them the single largest category. Soft plastic films and flexible plastics contribute ~6.8% by weight (17,321 g; 3,217 items), while foam (e.g., EPS) accounts for ~4.9% (12,560 g; 6,108 items).

Notably, textiles (18.1% by weight; 46,362 g) and shoes/sandals (16.9% of top-item weight ranking) also feature prominently, indicating that synthetic textile fabrics and footwear (often plastic-based) are a significant component of environmental leakage.

Additional indicators suggest that plastics dominate both surface and seafloor litter. Across surveyed sites, the total number of litter item types on the seafloor included 25 plastic types, versus 1 glass and 1 rubber type.

Surface litter densities also show strong variation by location: Byblos (~60,144) is far higher than Ibrahim River (~2,354), Litani River (~935), and Tyre (~659), indicating concentrated hotspots rather than uniform distribution.

Sediment monitoring reinforces that plastics persist beyond visible litter. For meso-/microplastics >700 μm, densities are higher overall: ~280 items/kg (Ibrahim), ~260 (Litani), ~246 (Tyre), and ~186 (Byblos). Polymer profiling (where available) indicates common consumer polymers dominate by count, especially HDPE and PP/PS, with LDPE and PET also significant, consistent with packaging, bottles, caps, films, and fragment sources.

lifeCycleInsights.title: Life Cycle Insights
keyTrends: {{country}}’s plastic trade was highly volatile between 2017 and 2022, with imports falling from 977 million to 419 million USD in 2020 before partially recovering to 746 million USD in 2022.
Exports surged in 2022 to 441 million USD, driven by primary polymer exports (278 million USD), significantly exceeding primary imports and reducing net domestic consumption.
Plastic consumption has structurally declined since 2017, falling from 772 million USD to 305 million USD in 2022, well below pre-pandemic levels.
Municipal solid waste generation is substantial (1,474 thousand tonnes in 2020) with 96% collection coverage, yet plastic leakage remains significant at 43,520 tonnes per year (8 kg/person/year).
Hard plastics, soft plastics and foam make up 77.7% of all marine litter on Lebanese beaches, with Beddaoui and Jadra identified as hotspots.
lifeCycleInsights.content:
{{country}}’s plastics economy is structurally import-dependent but volatile. Total plastic imports fell sharply from 977 million USD in 2017 to 419 million in 2020 before partially recovering to 746 million in 2022. Imports are dominated by primary polymers, tyres, and finished goods, indicating reliance on foreign resins, rubber manufacturing, and consumer products. Asia supplies over 70% of plastic imports.

Exports surged in 2022, driven by primary polymers. Primary plastic exports rose to 278 million USD in 2022, accounting for 65% of total exports. This sharp increase reduced net domestic consumption and indicates that more material left the economy than was absorbed internally.

Plastic consumption has structurally declined. Consumption fell from 772 million USD in 2017 to 305 million USD in 2022, reflecting broader economic instability, the 2020 contraction, and the 2022 export surge. Consumption remains well below pre-pandemic levels.

Waste management faces significant challenges despite high collection coverage. An estimated 1,474 thousand tonnes of MSW were generated in 2020, with 96% collection coverage. Yet annual plastic emissions including debris and open burning reach 43,520 tonnes (8 kg/person/year). Leakage occurs primarily at collection stages, with coastal municipalities like Tyre (6.6 kg/person/year) and Byblos (5.9 kg/person/year) showing highest per-capita leakage.

Marine litter is dominated by plastics. Hard plastics, soft plastics and foam make up 77.7% of all marine litter on Lebanese beaches. Beddaoui (Tripoli) and Jadra (Chouf) are persistent hotspots. Surface litter densities vary dramatically by location, with Byblos (~60,144 items) far exceeding other sites. Sediment monitoring shows persistent microplastic loads across riverine and coastal interfaces.
